bibl.title: Letter from John R. Taylor to Philip Showalter Hench, January 1, 1942

div1.p: Taylor informs Hench that he is the only living American who volunteered, was bitten by an infected mosquito, and nearly died in the Gorgas-Guiteras experiments.

div1.head: Letter from John R. Taylor to Philip Showalter Hench, January 1, 1942
div1.opener:
548 Grand Ave
Upper Darby, Pa
Jan 1st 1942.
Dr Phillip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn
Dear Dr Hench.
div1.p:
Am very glad to receive the copy
of the Proceedings of the Mayo Clinic containing
the article on “Conquerors of Yellow Fever.”
Was well acquainted with Dr Osler and more
so with Old Blockley, a place that, I was
very familiar with during the “eighties”.

I will not attempt to review your article,
except to congratulate you on getting together
a truthful story of the event. So much has been
written, some of it silly, some of it sarcastic,
that it is a pleasure to turn to your work
that has all the elements of careful collection.

In conclusion, I repeat that I am the only
living American, who volunteered, was bit, and
nearly died of yellow fever from the experiment.
Gorgas and Guiteras (not Reed commission) Of
eight volunteers, seven of us got yellow fever and
three of the seven died from the experiments.
Wishing you a Happy New Year.
